history.content:
I took math 54, physics 89, and ee16a/b series (not by choice, but it is what it is). I would say taking the whole of ee16a is my recommendation. 89 and 54 are mathematical approaches to linear algebra, which certainly makes ee16a easier. Even having a lot of experience with linear algebra coming into the class, I learned more of the computational approaches that the ee16 series takes. 

My friend was able to take EECS47 after taking math 54, but it was a harder adjustment to the labs and class style of ee16b. We were lab partners for EE16b, and they relied on me heavily for understanding the lab/circuit portion of the class. 


Tl;dr if you’re thinking about taking EECS47 you may as well take all of EE16a, ace the linear algebra portion, and enjoy the labs before it gets more difficult in EE16b

I am currently an intended CS major planning to take EE16a next semester with some questions. I am currently enrolled in Physics 89 (Introduction to Mathematical Physics) which covers concepts of linear algebra and differential equations (some say it is the physics equivalent of Math 54). I have also taken a Linear Algebra course over at another college institution (but not specifically a transferrable Math 54 credit as it did not cover differential equations). Therefore, I have a solid foundation in the concepts of linear algebra - which goes over the first module of the EE16a curriculum. I have heard of options such as EECS 47D (completion of EE16a) to essentially skip over the linear algebra portion part of the course and learn strictly the circuit modules. Do you think this is a good idea / even possible? If so, what are the specifics behind these courses and the process I would have to take to enroll?
Thank you so much.
history.subject: Should I enroll in EE16a?
